About me

Currently, I’m doing my PhD in psychology at Bar-Ilan University (Israel) under the supervision and guidance of Prof. Ruth Feldman from the Interdisciplinary Center Herzliya (Israel). In my PhD I look into how we synchronize to other people we’re interacting with through our autonomic measurements (e.g. heart rate, galvanic skin response), brain activity (using EEG), and hormones (mainly oxytocin, cortisol, testosterone). Lately, in addition to my research, I had the privilege to take part in other studies concerning mainly maternal depression, stressful environments, and PTSD.

Besides my studies, I enjoy analyzing new datasets and to teach and consult about research methods, statistics and data analysis. I preach for the use of R language, and in my spare time, I like photography, traveling, and listing to music.

Creating for loops in R
item.description:
Generally speaking, building loops in R is condemned and in some case might even be considered as blasphemy!. That been said, knowing and writing loops might be in some cases more efficient or useful than vectorizing. For example, (fortunately/unfortunately) R uses the computer’s RAM during calculations, thus in some cases memory issues might cause a function to crush/stop during “simple” vectorizing operation on big objects.

When creating loops we need to supply 4 arguments:

  1. iterator - index to iterate over
  2. start - where would we start?
  3. stop - when would we stop?
  4. what to do

Let’s try to understand more on how to build a loop from the flowing example:

for (i in 1:5) {
  
  print(i)

}

In this example, i is our iterator, 1 and 5 are our start and stop, and we print out our iterator. If we’d like to put it into words we can say: “for every i in 1 to 5 print i”.

Now, let’s run our loop and see what is happing:

i <- 1
for (i in 1:5) {
  
  print(i)

}
## [1] 1
## [1] 2
## [1] 3
## [1] 4
## [1] 5

Great! We managed to print our iterator correctly. Now, we can try to make things even more interesting. Using loops we can also iterate over vectors, data.frame, lists, etc.

We can build a vector of fruit names:

myVec <- c("apple", "banana", "orange")

Now, using a new loop, we can print each fruit:

i <- 1
for (i in 1:length(myVec)) {
  
  print(myVec[i])

}
## [1] "apple"
## [1] "banana"
## [1] "orange"

Here we have a few new things, first, the function length tells us how long is myVec. In our case 3, because we have 3 fruits.

length(myVec)
## [1] 3

In addition, we call the index ith of our vector. Which is same as doing below for each and every i.

myVec[1]
## [1] "apple"

If we’ll put our loop into words it will read like: “for every i in 1 to the length of myVec, print the value in each i index”.

The same can be applied for every type of indexed object in R. The only thing that we need to note is how the object is indexed. For example, we can also iterate over a data.frame. Example data.frame:

df <- data.frame(name = c("James", "Anne", "James II", "Mary II"), 
                 dob = c(1566, 1665, 1633, 1662), 
                 gender = c("male", "female", "male", "female"))

We can loop over the names in our data.frame (Please note the use of dim over length as length will give us the number of columns in a data.frame):

i <- 1
for (i in 1:dim(df)[1]) {
  
  print(df[i, "name"])

}
## [1] James
## Levels: Anne James James II Mary II
## [1] Anne
## Levels: Anne James James II Mary II
## [1] James II
## Levels: Anne James James II Mary II
## [1] Mary II
## Levels: Anne James James II Mary II

The date of birth:

i <- 1
for (i in 1:dim(df)[1]) {
  
  print(df[i, "dob"])

}
## [1] 1566
## [1] 1665
## [1] 1633
## [1] 1662

Lastly, we can build sentences using paste and print and loop over our data.frame

i <- 1
for (i in 1:dim(df)[1]) {
      print(
        paste("The ruler was", df[i, "name"], 
              "the date of birth was", df[i, "dob"], 
              "the gender was", df[i, "gender"]))
}
## [1] "The ruler was James the date of birth was 1566 the gender was male"
## [1] "The ruler was Anne the date of birth was 1665 the gender was female"
## [1] "The ruler was James II the date of birth was 1633 the gender was male"
## [1] "The ruler was Mary II the date of birth was 1662 the gender was female"

Thank you for reading!

item.title: Creating functions in R
item.description:
Building functions are one of the main building blocks in programming and in writing reproducible, easy to understand and readable code. In addition, it allows you to write what you need in a more efficient way and to detect errors more easily. Besides these important things, in most cases, your code will run faster. After I convinced you, I hope, we can start learning how to write functions.

Functions can do everything that you can code and ideally whenever you’re writing the same code more than twice you’ll make a function out of it.

To create a function we need to set the number of inputs the function we’ll take, what it will do, and to name the function (sometimes). Let’s start with the following example:

square <- function(x) { 
  out <- x^2
  return(out)
  }

We assigned the function to square, thus whenever we’d like to call the function we’ll use square(). Next, the function takes only one argument (x), the input will be squared and will get assigned to out. Lastly, using the base R function return, the function will return the value of out.

Practically, we don’t have to assign the function to out or use return in this example. However, getting used to using return is a good habit. Whenever we build a long function and we want to debug it, it’s always nice to look for the return and see what the function suppose to return.

Now, we can test our function to see if it actually return the expected results

square(2)
## [1] 4

And we can also use our function over a vector

myVec <- c(1:4)
print(myVec)
## [1] 1 2 3 4
square(myVec)
## [1]  1  4  9 16

We can even create more complicated function with two or three inputs (or more!). let’s create a function which calculate the Pythagorean theorem.

pythagorean <- function(x, y) { 
  out <- x^2 + y^2
  return(out)
}

We have two inputs (x and y) and will add the square value of both of them. The result will be assigned to out and will be reutrned. We can test our function

pythagorean(2, 4) 
## [1] 20

Thank you for reading!

item.title: Working with files and folders outside R
item.description:
When running an analysis, sometimes the need to change/create files and folder in our computer arises. For example when we might want to download many files at once to a specific folder or when we need to save temporary files of our analysis for later use to free our RAM.

Whenever we open an R session, R creates a temporary folder and will delete it when we close the R session. We can see our current temporary folder if we’ll run the function tempdir() without any arguments.

tempdir()
## [1] "C:\\Users\\Amir\\AppData\\Local\\Temp\\RtmpAzWHXo"

Now, let us say we want to download data, we wouldn’t like that the files that we downloaded will just “hang around” in the temporary folder. Thus, we can create a new folder inside the temp folder and save the files there. To create a new folder we can use the dir.create() function and paste() function to concatenate the temp folder (as it changes each time we open/close R) with the name of the folder we want. In addition, we can check if the folder was actually created using the dir.exists() function.

#Creating the new folder
dir.create(path = paste(
  tempdir(),
  "SaveHere", 
  sep = "/"))

#Check if the folder exists
dir.exists(paste(
  tempdir(),
  "SaveHere", 
  sep = "/"))
## [1] TRUE

Now, using the download.file() function, we can download the file to our new folder

#Save URL
urlCitation <- "https://github.com/AmirDJV/AmirDJV.github.io/blob/master/content/post/Converting_BibTeX_files_to_md_files/my_articles.bib"

#Save the location of the temp folder
whereToSave <- paste(tempdir(), "SaveHere", sep = "/")

#Download file
download.file(url = urlCitation,
              destfile = paste(whereToSave, "Citations.bib", sep = "/"))

We can also copy the file using the file.copy() function

file.copy(from = paste(whereToSave, "Citations.bib", sep = "/"), 
          to = paste(whereToSave, "Copy_Citations.bib", sep = "/"))
## [1] TRUE

We can use the list.files() function to see all the files in our folder. The arguments pattern and full name allows us to filter certain files extension and to display the full path of the files.

#In the folder we created
list.files(path = whereToSave,
           pattern = NULL,
           full.names = FALSE)
## [1] "Citations.bib"      "Copy_Citations.bib"

We can also change the argument recursive == TRUE, to test for files in sub folders

#In R's temp folder
list.files(path = tempdir(),
           pattern = NULL,
           full.names = TRUE,
           recursive = TRUE)
## [1] "C:\\Users\\Amir\\AppData\\Local\\Temp\\RtmpAzWHXo/file147020e43a16"           
## [2] "C:\\Users\\Amir\\AppData\\Local\\Temp\\RtmpAzWHXo/file147023635078"           
## [3] "C:\\Users\\Amir\\AppData\\Local\\Temp\\RtmpAzWHXo/file1470368d4d4b"           
## [4] "C:\\Users\\Amir\\AppData\\Local\\Temp\\RtmpAzWHXo/file147038457092"           
## [5] "C:\\Users\\Amir\\AppData\\Local\\Temp\\RtmpAzWHXo/file14705d4b1907"           
## [6] "C:\\Users\\Amir\\AppData\\Local\\Temp\\RtmpAzWHXo/file1470df4471e"            
## [7] "C:\\Users\\Amir\\AppData\\Local\\Temp\\RtmpAzWHXo/SaveHere/Citations.bib"     
## [8] "C:\\Users\\Amir\\AppData\\Local\\Temp\\RtmpAzWHXo/SaveHere/Copy_Citations.bib"

Lastly, if we’ll combine the functions that we used with file.remove() and do.call(), we can delete all the files we created

do.call(file.remove, list(list.files(whereToSave, full.names = TRUE)))
## [1] TRUE TRUE

Thank you for reading!

item.title: Converting BibTeX files to md files
item.description:
This is my first post! YAY!

While wondering around the amazing world of blog writing with blogdown package I had to choose a theme to work with. For now, I’ve chosen the hugo academic theme due to recommendations over the web and it’s so called easy interface and “out of the box” utilities.

The first problem that I had to tackle was how to post my publications. Thus to convert my library of publications which were saved as one BibTeX file. Luckily I found a package that was written just for that.

I started with installing from github the required packages.

# If not installed, you should install "devtools" and "bib2academic"
if (!require("devtools")) install.packages("devtools")
## Loading required package: devtools
if (!require("bib2academic")) devtools::install_github("petzi53/bib2academic")
## Loading required package: bib2academic
#Load package
require(bib2academic)

If you’d like to try while reading, I uploaded my BibTeX file to github.

So, now we need to start the conversion of the BibTeX file to multiple .bib files and .md files. This can be done using the “bib2acad” function. Note that instead of writing a direct path, I “pasted” the working directory and the directory of the file.

bib2acad(paste(getwd(),
               "content/post/Converting_BibTeX_files_to_md_files/my_articles.bib", 
               sep = "/"),
         copybib = TRUE, abstract = TRUE, overwrite = TRUE)
## Cannot find file 'C:/Amir/Dropbox/MySite/AmirDJV.github.io/content/post/content/post/Converting_BibTeX_files_to_md_files/my_articles.bib'. Check path and/or file name.

If everything went smoothly, we should now see in our working directory two new folders “my-bib-folder” (which holds all the BibTeX files) and “my-md-folder (which holds all the .md files).

Next, we should move these files to there correct path. To do that, we should first get a list of all the files inside the folders:

bibFiles <- list.files("my-bib-folder", full.names = TRUE)
mdFiles <- list.files("my-md-folder", full.names = TRUE)

Now we can copy them to the correct path:

file.copy(from = bibFiles, to = "static/files/citations/")
## logical(0)
file.copy(from = mdFiles, to = "content/publication/")
## logical(0)

Lastly, we should delete the temp folders we created

unlink("my-bib-folder", recursive = T, force = T)
unlink("my-md-folder", recursive = T, force = T)

All that is left is to rebuild our site and to see that the updates took place as we expected

#If you wish to clean and rebuild the site from start.
# rmarkdown::clean_site()

#If you wish to build the site with out preview
# blogdown::build_site()

#If you wish to build and preview the site
# blogdown::serve_site()
